article:

Mountains of California in 1994. The raised second cockpit is for the
instructor.|alt= Dryden's SR-71B Blackbird, NASA 831, slices across the snow-
covered southern Sierra Nevada Mountains of California after being refueled by
an Air Force tanker during a 1994 flight. SR-71B was the trainer version of the
SR-71. The dual cockpit to allow the instructor to fly. Note the streaks of fuel
from refueling spillage. }}{{Infobox aircraft type |type= Strategic

Clarence "Kelly" Johnson |first flight= 22 December 1964 |introduced= 1966

|variants with their own articles = }}

The 'Lockheed SR-71 "Blackbird"' was an advanced, long-range, Mach 3+
strategic reconnaissance aircraft. [http://www.lockheedmartin.com/us/100years/programs/sr-71-
blackbird.html "SR-71 Blackbird."] lockheedmartin.com. Retrieved: 14 March
2010. It was developed as a black project from the Lockheed A-12
reconnaissance aircraft in the 1960s by Lockheed and its Skunk Works division.
Clarence "Kelly" Johnson was responsible for many of the design's innovative
concepts. During reconnaissance missions, the SR-71 operated at high speeds and
altitudes to allow it to outrace threats. If a surface-to-air missile launch was
detected, the standard evasive action was simply to accelerate and outfly the
missile. "SR71 Blackbird." PBS documentary,
Aired: 15 November 2006.

The SR-71 served with the U.S. Air Force from 1964 to 1998. A total of 32
aircraft were built; 12 were lost in accidents, and none was lost to enemy
action. Landis and Jenkins 2005, pp. 98,
100â101. The SR-71 has been given several
nicknames, including [[Common Blackbird|Blackbird]] and [[Trimeresurus
flavoviridis|Habu]]. Since 1976, it has held the
world record for the fastest air-breathing manned aircraft, a record previously
held by the YF-12. Landis and Jenkins 2005, p.
78. Pace 2004, pp. 159.
